Award.AwardTitle: Using Math Pathways & Pitfalls to Promote Algebra Readiness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Summary
Using Math Pathways & Pitfalls to Promote Algebra Readiness is a 4-year Full Research and Development project that creates a set of materials for middle grades students and teacher professional development that would support the learning of early algebra. Building on their prior work with an elementary version, the efficacy study focuses on the implementation of the principals underlying the materials, fidelity of use of the materials, and impact on students' learning.
The project's goals are to: 1) develop an MPP book and companion materials dedicated to algebra readiness content and skills, 2) investigate how MPP transforms pedagogical practices to improve students' algebra readiness and metacognitive skills, and 3) validate MPP's effectiveness for improving students' algebra readiness with a large-scale randomized controlled trial.

The iterative design and efficacy studies produce research-based materials to increase student learning of core concepts in algebra readiness. Though the focus of the project is algebra readiness, the study also examines the validity of the pedagogical approach of MPP. The MPP lesson structures are designed to help students confront common misconceptions, dubbed "pitfalls," through sense-making, class discussions, and the use of multiple visual representations. If the pedagogical approach of MPP proves to be successful, the lesson structures can be presented as an effective framework for instruction that extends to other content areas in mathematics and other disciplines.

The project addresses a critical need in education, and the potential impact is large. Math achievement in the U.S. is not keeping pace with international performance. The current project focuses on algebra readiness skills, an area that is critical for future success in mathematics. Algebra often serves as a gatekeeper to more advanced mathematics, and performance in algebra has been linked to success in college and long-term earnings potential. Longitudinal studies indicate that students taking rigorous high school mathematics courses are twice as likely to graduate from college as those who do not. Thus, adequately preparing students for algebra can dramatically affect educational outcomes for students. The current project broadens the participation of underrepresented groups of students in math and later science classes that require strong math skills. The intervention builds on materials and pedagogical techniques that have demonstrated positive outcomes for diverse students. The targeted districts have large samples of English language learners and students from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM so that we may evaluate the impact of the intervention on these populations. At the end of the project, the publication quality materials will be readily available to teachers and districts through our website www.wested.org/mpp.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Using Math Pathways & Pitfalls to Promote Algebra Readiness project set out to develop a book of lessons and companion materials to promote 7th grade students' algebra readiness. These lessons have now been published online as a freely available e-book at https://www.wested.org/resources/mpp-beta/.

There are ten lessons in the Math Pathways & Pitfalls (MPP): Algebra Readiness sequence, each of which addresses a particular mathematical misconception, or pitfall, that is related to students' success in algebra. The lessons are aligned to the 7th grade Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSS-M) and the Standards for Mathematical Practice (SMPs). The ten lessons and their objectives are:

1. Signed number addition and subtraction.
Interpret and solve problems involving addition and subtraction of signed numbers (7.NS.A.1, MP1, MP3).

2. Products and quotients of signed numbers.
To reason about products and quotients of signed numbers (7.NS.A.2, MP2, MP3).

3. Complex fractions.
To simplify complex fractions (7.NS.A.3, MP3, MP6).

4. Simplifying expressions.
To use the properties of operations to simplify expressions (7.EE.A.1, MP1, MP2, MP3).

5. Solving linear equations I.
To solve linear equations involving one operation (7.EE.B.4, 7.NS.A.1, 7.NS.A.2, MP3, MP6).

6. Solving linear equations II.
To solve linear equations involving two operations (7.EE.B.4, MP3, MP6).

7. Solving linear equations III.
To solve linear equations in which the coefficient of the variable is negative (7.EE.B.4, MP3, MP6).

8. Representing proportional relationships.
To write equations to represent proportional relationships (7.RP.A.2, MP2, MP3).

9. Writing equations to solve word problems.
To solve word problems by writing and solving equations (7.EE.B.4, MP1, MP2, MP3).

10. Enlargements and reductions.
To solve problems involving perimeter, area, and volume of enlarged or reduced objects (7.G.A.1, 7.G.B.6, 7.RP, A.2, MP2, MP3).

The lessons can be used with any core curriculum. Each lesson is designed to take two class periods with an optional homework assignment. The e-book includes teaching guides, student workbook pages, and other supporting material.

Intellectual Merit

The MPP: Algebra Readiness lessons are based on the original Math Pathways & Pitfalls K-8 intervention and enrichment curriculum authored by Carne Barnett-Clarke, Alma Ramirez, and Debra Coggins. The original curriculum was developed over a decade, with grants from multiple funders, and showed positive effects for students in a randomized efficacy trial. 

The MPP: Algebra Readiness lessons were developed through an iterative process that incorporated findings from research, expert review, and several types of research and evaluation.

We began this project with a survey of teachers using the original MPP materials, identifying how they were implementing the materials in their classrooms and what they found challenging. We revised the MPP lesson format in response to this survey. We also conducted an extensive review of research on barriers to learning algebra. We identified a series of common misconceptions that, if left unaddressed, can lead students to struggle with algebra. This list of misconceptions, combined with the revised MPP lesson format, became the foundation for our algebra readiness book.

The book development process included multiple cycles of field-testing and evaluation in northern and southern California. We developed a prototype lesson and field-tested it with two teachers. We then developed a full suite of draft lessons and field-tested them in two cycles. The first cycle included five teachers. The second cycle included thirteen teachers. A panel of experts in math education reviewed the draft lessons and provided feedback on content and pedagogy during each cycle. Finally, the lessons were tested in a small quasi-experimental study, which was inconclusive as to the lessons' impact on students' 7th grade mathematics achievement. As a result, we consider the lessons to still be in a prototype or testing phase rather than a finished supplementary curriculum. 

Broader Impacts

By making the lessons freely available, we hope that they can be tested by a greater number of teachers nationwide. We invite middle school math teachers to download and use the materials in their own classrooms and share feedback with WestEd to inform further refinements to the lessons.
